Step 3. Determine the range of f(A).
Since cos²A is always in the interval [0, 1] for all real A, one might at first suspect that f(A) would range over [3, 4]. However, note the domain restriction A ≠ nπ/2:
 • cos²A = 0 if cos A = 0, i.e. A = π/2 + kπ (with k any integer). These A values are excluded.
 • cos²A = 1 if cos A = ±1, i.e. A = kπ. These are also excluded because kπ is a multiple of π/2 when k is even.
Thus, while cos²A can get arbitrarily close to 0 or 1, it never equals exactly 0 or 1. This means that in our expression f(A) = 3 + cos²A, the term cos²A takes on values in the open interval (0, 1).
